text: The first wave of late-morning customers crowds in, snowmelt trailing across the floor. Chair legs scrape in sharp bursts, like a string of small explosions.
I’m still deciding who to greet first when Alicia ties an apron around her waist—like fastening the final buckle of armor.
“Two tables want stew. One bread. One hot wine.”
“How do you—”
“I can smell it.”
She lifts a tray and walks off. Not fast—but never a wasted step. The tray in her hands is as steady as if nailed to the air.
One of the customers laughs and makes a crude remark, pointing at her.
“Drink if you’re drinking.”
“If not, shut your mouth before the soup gets cold.”
The man’s grin stiffens. Someone beside him tugs his sleeve. The entire table goes quiet—like they’ve suddenly remembered an unspoken rule.
She doesn’t spare them another glance. She sets down the wine and taps the table lightly. A clear, precise sound—like a signal that the matter is settled.
“You’ll scare off customers doing business like that.”
“No.”
“The ones who scare easily usually can’t afford to pay.”
When she says it, there’s the faintest spark of satisfaction in her expression—brief as an ember. Something different. Something almost fresh.
She turns to the next table, shifting tasks like changing formation in battle.
Pouring wine. Refilling stew. Taking coin. Wiping tables. Every motion executed as if practiced countless times.
I pass her a plate of fresh stew from the kitchen. When she takes it, her fingers brush mine—and pause for a second.
“See?”
“This is what I want.”
“What?”
“No blades. No blood.”
“You hand me a plate. I put it down. And then—it’s over.”
Her voice is quiet, but beneath it is a sentence she doesn’t say aloud: I haven’t lived like this in too long.
By afternoon, the rush thins out. She slides the last coin into my palm, like turning over spoils after a campaign.
“Being the innkeeper’s wife isn’t bad.”
“The victories here are simple: customers are fed, the wine stays hot, and you’re not hurt.”
When she says you’re not hurt, her eyes drop instinctively to my hands—like inspecting something she has sworn to protect.
For a fleeting second, she looks like she’s back in her true role—not carrying plates, but guarding something so fiercely she’d rather die than see it break.
